guide.title: Gentoo Linux Release Policy
guide.abstract: The Offical Gentoo Linux Release Policy

section.title: What is the Gentoo Linux release process?

body.p: The Gentoo Linux release process is the clearly-defined and documented procedure that the Gentoo Linux development team uses to create new release candidates and new official releases of Gentoo Linux. In practice, it is meant to be a team-based, coordinated effort that involves every member of the development team.

section.title: Who is "in charge" of the Gentoo Linux release process?

body.p: While the Release Process is coordinated by the Release Coordinator and the releng team, the process itself is a team effort. There is no one person responsible for doing all or even the majority of the work. It is the responsibility of the Release Coordinator to involve the entire team in the release process, by doing things like posting regular updates to the -core mailing list to keep everyone abreast of the current release status, coordinating with those managing the building of stage tarballs and GRP package sets, and those performing QA testing.

section.title: Goals of the Gentoo Linux release process

ul.li: On-time release of a new release candidate or full version of Gentoo Linux.
Proper QA testing on the new release.
Opportunity for stable changes to get into the release.
To make the release process a *team* process
Ensure that new official versions of Gentoo Linux are ready for the public.

chapter.title: How the Gentoo Linux release process works

body.p: The release process starts with an official decision to release a new version of Gentoo Linux, made by the top level management team, who then present:

ul.li: A clear schedule for the release process, including all milestones and deadlines.
A specific list of goals for this release (optional).

body.p: The Release Coordinator then guides the release process, ensuring that the necessary release infrastructure is in place and functioning cohesively. The release coordinator then informs all developers of the start of the next phase, which begins immediately.

In this phase, assigned builders for each architecture build a "generic CPU" set of stage tarballs using a current Portage snapshot, and report/fix/create bugs to fix any build-related bugs found. In addition, our initial QA testers use these stages and report any runtime bugs found.

As new bugs in the stage tarballs are found and fixed, new releases of the stage tarballs are rolled up. These stage tarballs are posted on a publicly-accessible Web site so that testing can begin by developers and users recruited for QA efforts.

A week after beginning, this "build an test" phase switches from using a *current* CVS tree to using the official GENTOO_x.y_SNAP_YYYYMMDDAB snapshot of the CVS tree. An effort is made to resolve all outstanding build/runtime issues. As bugs are fixed, new GENTOO_x.y_SNAP_YYYYMMDDAB (with new date) tags are made, and these new snapshots are used to build new bug-fixed stage tarballs.

Ten days after the beginning of the "build and test" phase, a determination is made as to whether this next release will be an "official release" or release candidate. The Development Lead for each arch, the Release Coordinator, the Development Manager, and the Chief Architect all come to a final unanimous decision in this matter.

If quality is not where it should be, the next release should be a release candidate. If quality is good, all goals for the release have been met and major issues are resolved or resolvable in a reasonable time, then the next release should be an official release.
The latest GENTOO_x.y_SNAP_YYYYMMDDAB snapshot is used for this release. With generic stage tarballs for this snapshot in hand, the next phase begins...

Immediately, a large-scale, coordinated distributed build effort begins to build the full new Gentoo Linux release or release candidate, including GRP package sets. If release candidate, a smaller subset of system variants (ie, i686 and maybe one more for x86) may be optionally chosen instead of a "full" build. During this build process, any last-minute quirks are ironed out. Install documentation is updated for the new release. Release announcements are written, but not yet made public. And private QA testing of the final release binaries begin as soon as they have finished compiling. This is our final QA verification before release.
This entire phases, including creation of LiveCDs and uploading to mirrors, should complete in no more than 4 days.
The new version or release candidate of Gentoo Linux is released and announcements are posted in the relevant locations.
